I saw enough YouTube clips of this documentary to know that the arguments made in this movie are not based on fact, nor on a real understanding of the history of the SDA Church or the proper place of Ellen White in the movement. Having studied theology at an Adventist university and having worked for awhile at the Ellen White Estate there, I know more about the church than this document claims to tell.

First off, Ellen White was not *the* founder of the SDA church. If anything, she was one of a dozen people who were involved at the beginning. Second, I agree with other reviewers here: just because a few people on the fringe might quote Ellen White as if she is equal to the Bible doesn't mean that's what the denomination teaches. SDA's don't put Ellen White on the same level of the Bible, because even though they see her as inspired by God, they look to the Bible alone as the only authority by which all else is to be tested. In other words, you could throw out Ellen White and still believe the same doctrines of the SDA church. That's why SDA's are SO unconcerned that people accuse Ellen White of copying a lot of her work from other people as was common practice among Christian writers back then, because it doesn't change the teachings that are based on the Bible.

In fact, I think the BIGGEST misconception is that SDA theology came out of nowhere, as if it was all based on one person's writings. Thousands of Christians from varying denominations had joined in the Millerite movement and the Great Disappointment because they had come to the same conclusions based on historicist interpretations of Bible prophecies, and this was BEFORE Ellen White. Actually, SDA theology is a continuing development of Protestant theology, borrowing from Baptists and Methodists. Ellen White herself was a former Methodist and many of her teachings are a further refinement of John Wesley and others. Nevertheless, SDA theology was not "founded" by Ellen White, but rather it was developed and refined by a group of people over a period of time. Perhaps it's easier for people to attack SDA's and blame SDA theology on one person than to admit that SDA's actually borrowed many teachings from their own churches and developed them further!

This "documentary" is more of a witch hunt against the SDA church than anything else. It tries to connect SDA's with all kinds of crazy fringe things that the church itself rejected. Furthermore it gives the typical misconception that SDA's view White as equal with the Bible. From my research they view her as inspired, but not at the same level with the Bible. Their fundamental belief #18 states "as the Lord's messenger, her [White's] writings are a continuing and authoritative source of truth which provide for the church comfort, guidance, instruction, and correction." They also make clear that "the Bible is the standard by which all teaching and experience must be tested", showing that they hold the Bible as higher. There are a few SDA's that may view them equally but those are largely on the fringe of the religion. Even though some of the SDA's beliefs are dif. than typical evangelical protestantism calling them a cult is way too extreme and misleading.
